text: Family Member: So would you suggest that he goes and see Dr. ____ uh when he’s scheduled or; now tomorrow he’s going to see - Patient: Another urologist. Family Member: A urologist that saw him up in the hospital, which is up in our area. Doctor: Yeah, I know that Dr. ____ reached out to you after you got to the hospital. So you know what he feels he can do versus there; most of what it sounds like is very just bread-and-butter urology. And you know um, we saw ya and we were worried that your kidney function had taken a bump. And it just got worse. And that’s why I want him to check it within a few days. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: And within that few days it had already gotten worse and because your kidney function was bad, that makes you have nausea and then you sort of – Patient: Right. Doctor: They come in, which, and you know when they looked at your picture um it really was where this was all started — that’s the problem because you can tell just by them just having to put a catheter in, that uh once your bladder gets empty and kidney functions get better. Patient: Right. Doctor: Uh yeah so those are issues we have to talk about whether or not there is any role for radiation even though that’s not going to fix the big problem. It may help you pee better. Patient: Uh hum. Family Member: Um now since the cancer has spread, that the main problem

text: Family Member: Okay. And that’s the injection he has? Doctor: No. Family Member: No? Doctor: No. The injection he has right now is uh, the hormone therapy, the Lupron. Family Member: Yeah. text: Patient: Right. Doctor: And so do we just sort of like stay low or if you get better, if the prostate shrinks and we are able to get the catheter out, then we did the right thing. Or if time goes on and you still have trouble getting that catheter out, uh would radiation help? Is it because the drugs aren’t doing what they need to do to shrink it to allow you to have a reasonable channel to get the pee out? Um and that’s sort of – before when we had chemo and before we had these super hormones, some of us would send you to radiation. And then now we don’t know because you can’t get the radiation and the chemo and the hormone all at the same time. Family Member: Right. Doctor: Because that’s just way too much. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So if he’s not on a clinical trial, I don’t get new pictures. Family Member: Ah, okay. Okay. text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So on the clinical study, we do scan him more than he would get if he was not on the clinical trial because we’re giving you more therapy than what’s usual, and they wouldn’t want us to keep giving you drugs that they’re not helping, and so they They want the actual data about scans. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So that would be a potential good thing for you. If you want more information, the study gives you more of that information. Family Member: Right. Doctor: But how I make decisions, I don’t necessarily need those scans. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: But I want to make sure on the studies everybody gets pictures of the same time points so that we can see when the cancer changes. Patient: And another question that I have. At one point we talked to acupuncturist and he said he can help through acupuncture with peeing problems. So and I was thinking we’d go on the day when we take the catheter our, but now I’m thinking maybe I should wait. And now if that is okay, see if that may be some additional help. Doctor: I don’t know. I think it’s reasonable to try. You know most acupuncturists will ask you about your current situation – Patient: Right. Doctor: - and see how well it would help. You know my worry is you know if you’re spending money on that then how does it help? You know if they are doing it and you get the catheter out is it because of my drug or because they gave you, you know acupuncture and how long you paid them?

text: Family Member: He thought it was better for the body. Doctor: Yeah, it’s not as a home run, you know, there’s nothing that tells me we should do it off road to do that at this moment. Patient: Yeah, okay. Doctor: That’s probably the best way to say it. Nothing that says oh, man, this abstract tells me this is like a home run. No, I think it just adds more side effects. Patient: Yeah, okay, good, okay Doctor: Yeah, so, I know prostate cancer is the one cancer we can’t seem to plot. We love combining stuff. Patient: Right. Doctor: We’re all like crazy mad scientists in the back. Go, here’s what I, look, that’s what we like to do but with prostate cancer every time we do that it doesn’t behave. It either does nothing but give you more side effects or it just causes a problem. You know, like if you combine this with Zytiga you get more fractures. That’s no good. Patient: Right, I remember you saying that at one of our visits you were saying that. Doctor: Yeah and so just because theoretically like well, they should kind of work together. Patient: Right, Right. Doctor: It just doesn’t so we learned most of the drugs in prostate cancer it’s not like the other cancers where you do two or three drugs together. You know, we’re kind of like the loner group so it’s one at a time, sequence matters with one. Family Member: So this other doctor is going to explain the side effects he may get from radiation?

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
